awd_titl_txt: Computational Studies of Protein Powder Hydration Phenomena
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract
This PI will use advanced molecular simulation tools to investigate and quantify the effects of key variables such as hydration level, carbohydrate excipients, and temperature on the structure, stability and dynamics of proteins undergoing dehydration and rehydration. The impact from the successful outcome of this project will help develop quality therapeutic proteins and advance the development such therapeutics for the pharmaceutical industry.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project has been to investigate computationally the effects of temperature and water content on the structure, dynamics and thermodynamics of protein powders. Such powders are commonly used to store and preserve proteins over long periods of time, for example in the pharmaceutical industry, but basic aspects of their physical chemistry remain poorly understood. Another objective of this work has been the computational investigation of the effects of cold on the structure, stability and thermodynamics of proteins in aqueous solution. The main outcomes of this project are listed below. 

(1) Using advanced computational techniques developed in our laboratory, we showed that water adsorption isotherms (water content of a protein as a function of relative humidity) are insensitive to the type of protein matrix on which the water adsorbs (crystalline, amorphous, thermally denatured). 

(2) We showed that the nonlinear dimensionality reduction technique known as diffusion maps is a computationally effective means of identifying the folding pathways of proteins. 

(3) We demonstrated the existence of two transition temperatures at which the dynamics of protein powders changes suddenly. For the 20 amino-acid miniprotein used in our calculations (Trp-cage), a low-temperature transition occurs at roughly 160K, and is independent of water content. At around 220K, a second transition occurs, the precise location of which depends on water content. At this higher-temperature transition, vibrational motions lose their harmonic character. 

(4) We studied the unfolding of the Trp-cage miniprotein upon cooling, using advanced computational techniques. We were able to compute the free energy, enthalpy and entropy changes upon unfolding across a 300K-wide temperature range. We found that low-temperature unfolding is favored energetically, but disfavored entropically. We identified the main source of this energetic stabilization, namely interactions between water and polar amino-acids along the protein backbone. Cold-unfolded states involve disruption of the protein’s hydrophobic core, but basic elements of Trp-cage’s secondary structure, such as the alpha helix, remain intact.

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2016
Modified by: Pablo G Debenedetti
